front.title: Methods for Detection and Mitigation of BGP Route Leaks

author.organization: USA National Institute of Standards and Technology

front.keyword: BGP, Route Leak Detection, Route-Leak Mitigation, BGP Security

abstract.t: Problem definition for route leaks and enumeration of types of route leaks are provided in RFC 7908. This document describes a inter-AS (multi-hop) solution for detection and mitigation route leaks which is based on conveying route-leak detection information in two new well-known BGP communities: route leak detection community (RLD) and route leak notification community (RLN). These communities gives ISPs an easy way to detect route leaks, and, if needed, propagate information about such incidents. This solution complements the intra-AS (local AS) route-leak avoidance solution that is described in ietf-idr-bgp-open-policy draft.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: RFC 7908 provides a definition of the route leak problem, and enumerates several types of route leaks. For this document, the definition that is applied is that a route leak occurs when a route received from a transit provider or a lateral peer is forwarded (against commonly used policy) to another transit provider or a lateral peer. The commonly used policy is that a route received from a transit provider or a lateral peer may be forwarded only to customers.

This document describes a solution for detection and mitigation route leaks which is based on conveying route-leak information in a Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) community. These document specified two well-known communities for these purpose - route leak detection (RLP) and route leak notification (RLN) community. Its configuration policies MUST be defined according to peering relations between ISPs. If BGP Roles described in are configured, community configuration SHOULD be implemented in code of routing software.

Described technique can be incrementally deployed. If a group of big ISPs or/and IXes deploy proposed route marking, then they would be helping each other by blocking route leaks that can happen between them.

section.title: Peering Relationships
section.t: If the route is announced to a customer or RS-client it MUST go 'only down' and should not be received by other ISPs from links with customers, peers or received by IX route server. So, we need a transit signal that will tell a remote ISP that receiving prefix violates 'only down' rule and thus providing a way to stop the propagation of leaked prefixes.

section.title: Route-Leak Detection Community
section.t:
The are three rules that enable detection of route leaks:
If route with RLD community set is received from Customer or RS-client - it's a route leak If route with RLD community set is received from Peer and RLD value isn't equal to neighbor ASN - it's a route leak If route with RLN community set is received from any eBGP session (see bellow) - it's a route leak
This three rules provide an easy way to detect policy violation at the per-prefix granularity.

section.title: Route-Leak Notification Community
section.t: In the previous section was described as a method to detect route leaks. In this section will be discussed different options what ISP SHOULD do if route leak is detected. The straightforward way is to reject leaked routes. But such filtering strategy might have side-effects.

If the prefix has a single path to Tier1 providers its whole connectivity depends on this path existence. And if this path is leaked, and rejected afterward by transit ISP, including Tier1, it will make this prefix partially unavailable. So, in this case, the victim may experience DoS because of the mistake of the third party. We found that more than connectivity of 100 thousand of prefixes (about 15% of all prefixes in the today full view table) relies on a single from origin to Tier1 path and thus can be affected. The deprioritization is a soft way to stop route leak propagation that solves the problem of possible outages.

But propagation of leaked should be also done with caution. When the prefix is received from provider RLD community can't be used to tell if the route was leaked or not. And if it was leaked it may result in BGP wedges scenario or even create a stable oscillation with dynamic BGP loops.

section.title: Route-Leak Notification Mitigation
section.t: In previous were described ways to detect route leaks using RLD and RLN communities. In this section will be presented suggested method for route leak mitigation.

If leaked prefix is learned from RS-client it MUST be rejected If leaked prefix is learned from Peer, Provider or RS and network has default route it MUST be rejected Otherwise LOCALE PREF MUST be be set to 0 and RLN community MUST be added
This rule complements detection measures via RLD community described in previous section.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: With the use of BGP community, there is often a concern that the community propagates beyond its intended perimeter and causes harm . However, that concern does not apply to the RLD and RLN communities because it is a transitive community that must propagate as far as the update goes.

The proposed route leak information carried in the RLD and RLN communities can benefit from cryptographic protection to prevent abuse by malicious actors in the AS path. In the future, if there is BGPsec deployment, the RLP and RLN information can be encoded in the Flags field in the Secure_Path Segment in BGPsec updates . So, the cryptographic security mechanisms in BGPsec can also secure the route leak detection information. The reader is directed to the security considerations provided in .

section.title: IANA Considerations
section.t: The draft suggests to reserve Global Administrator ID 4200000000 for transit well-known large community registry. IANA is requested to register RLN and RLD in the well-known large community registry.
